comments.author: Rani Hinnawi

comments.text:
V=(1/3)Bh
V=(1/3)(pir^2)r
V=(1/3)(pir^3)

Area of Sphere classically:(4/3)pir^3
let's say the radius of a sphere is 2. I am using only 3.14 for pi.
V=(1/3)pi*2^3
V=(1/3)pi*8
V=(1/3)25.12
V approx.=8.373

V=(4/3)pir^3
V=(4/3)pi*2^3
V=(4/3)pi*8
V=(4/3)25.12
V approx.=33.493
33.493/4 approx.=8.373.
We can then conclude that this formula only shows the Volume of half of a 
circle. So, the relationship would be: 4*(1/3)Bh=(4/3)pir^3 OR 
(4/3)Bh=(4/3)pir^3. This is all just a fancy way of saying the formula 
V=1/3Bh gives the volume of a quarter of a sphere, and that the formulas 
cannot be used the same without multiplying by 4 first. You are basically 
doing the same steps but it is just shown as a different formula.﻿

comments.author: Marco Friz

comments.text:
I think it's a dopy proof. The standard one is easier to understand and 
more direct. One only needs to know the definition of pi, the area of a 
triangle, and draw a very narrow triangle with a vertex at the center of 
the circle. For N triangles, the narrow base of each one is about 2*pi*R/N, 
its height is R, so its area is pi*R^2/N, and so on. It's 8th grade math. 
Cutting up the little chains in this video was more complicated! How does 
this get nearly 2 million hits?!﻿
comments.author: James Mark

comments.author: Menea6587

comments.text:
+Menea6587 It is not necessary to go through the definition of the Riemann 
integral each time, or to use the Green theorem (∬dx∧dy=∮½(xdy-ydx)).

The correct approach (taking the symmetry into account) is, 
A=∬dx∧dy=∬d(rcosϑ)∧d(rsinϑ)=∬[(cosϑdr-rsinϑdϑ)∧(sinϑdr+rcosϑdϑ)]=∬[rcos²ϑdr∧dϑ-rsin²ϑdϑ∧dr]=∬rdr∧dϑ=∫rdr∫dϑ=πR².

If you don't understand the above then read & learn, or find yourself 
another passtime.
comments.author: LeconsdAnalyse

comments.text:
Well
1) that method requires a working knowledge of how to limits and 
trigonometry. Neither of those are really 8th grade.
2) If you're going to bring up calculus, then you just know that the 
integral over the boundary of a curve is equal to the area bounded by the 
curve. Thus, just integrate 2pi*r to get pi*r^2 with no need for taking the 
limit of the sum of the area of shrinking triangles.
3) you don't need to know the definition of pi, just that it's a constant 
in this case.
4) The "standard" proof that I was exposed to was splitting a circle up 
into pizza slices with arcs very nearly flat and then arranging them into a 
pseudo-parallelogram. Thus, the area is the height (r) times the length (pi 
r).

comments.author: Docteur Zeuhl

comments.text:
+Docteur Zeuhl​ It's obvious that it can be turned into a triangle. But if 
you insist a complete proof, here it is.

The proof consists of two parts. To proof they both have the same area, 
first we need to show the base layer is the same. Second, we need to show 
that for each dS in radius we decrease, the area shrunk is linear since the 
side of the triangle is linear.

The outermost ring in the circle has a radius of r, and is dR wide. The 
area would be 2πrdR.
For the triangle, he defined the bottom side to be 2πr, which gives us an 
area of 2πrdR.
So they are the same.

Now, if we shrink the ring by an infinitesimal amount dS, we get an area of 
2π(r-dS)dR. The difference between the larger ring and the smaller ring in 
area will be 2πrdR - 2π(r - dS)dR = 2πdRdS

Here, it shows that each "smaller" rings will have an area smaller by a 
constant amount. This holds true for every r you pick, which r < R, the 
radius of the circle, or the height of the triangle.

Since both bases have the same area, and they both decreases by a constant 
amount when r (radius in circle or height in triangle) gets smaller, and I 
have showed that for all r, that means they both have the same area.

comments.text:
+John Seller 

Claim: C=2piR

Proof:

By definition, pi=C/(2r). Multiplying both sides by 2r, we get 2r*pi=C, and 
rearranging we obtain C=2piR. 

QED.

Impressed?

comments.author: iMakHugo

comments.text:
It's really easy if you space it out properly and not group it in all as a 
whole:

To find out the area of the circle is really simple: pi * 2*r OR pi * d.

pi = 3.141, and r (The Radius, or the blue line that goes from the center 
to the circumference, perimeter.) can equal whatever. d (diameter) is just 
double the radius

The equation at the beginning says: 1/2b*h which is the formula for a 
triangle.

Filling in the gaps for b and h is what comes next. Where it says = is 
basically just breaking it up and showing that b and h is DEFINED as.

1/2b*h = 1/2(2piR) * R is basically just saying, b = Half of 2*pi*Radius, h 
= Radius. All together it's saying that it all equals the formula for pi: 
pi*R^2 (Radius Squared)

Hopefully you understand this, and your english is coming along nicely, 
keep up the good work!

comments.text:
soooo, it is actually pretty simple: 
We want to caculate the area of a circle, here it goes:
-Making a circle out of chains
-Transforming it into a triangle with the same area
-Caculating the area of the triangle, which is the same as for the circle
Calculations:
-The perimeter of the circle (2*pi*r)=the basis of the triangle
-The radius of the circle=the height of the triangle
Therefore, the area of the triangle= 1/2*basis*height=1/2*2*pi*r*r, which 
can be simplified in pi*r^2.This is equal to the area of the circle, Done !

should work AFAIK.

comments.text:

you zoom in enough you'll see curves? Anyway, human-made circles may not be 
perfect. But mathematically they can. All you need is the formula x²+y²=r²
comments.author: MrMaestro14231

comments.text:
Thing is,  I believe that you can't create a real curve. It has to be 
composed of so many lines that when you look far enough, you'll see a 
curve. So, it's possible to turn a circle into a line for me, I guess.
comments.author: bestinmathagent

comments.text:
In the real world, that would true. To take a circle, split it on one side 
the length of the radius, it would be awkward to shape it into a triangle. 
You'd have to imagine it's Play-Doh. With this proof there are some 
inconsistencies. The gap in the circle at the beginning becomes the spaces 
between the chains and the triangle later. It's definitely not exact, which 
is why mathematicians demand the use of calculus for such problems. But 
it's close enough to be one additional proof to the many others
comments.author: Zachary Anderson
